question:
Show that $f: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}$, given by
$$f(x)=\begin{cases}x+1,&\text{if } x \text{ is odd}\\x-1,&\text{if } x \text{ is even}\end{cases}$$
is both one-one and onto.
solution:
Suppose $f(x_1) = f(x_2)$. 

Note that if $x_1$ is odd and $x_2$ is even, then we will have $x_1 + 1 = x_2 - 1$, i.e., $x_2 - x_1 = 2$ which is impossible. 

Similarly, the possibility of $x_1$ being even and $x_2$ being odd can also be ruled out, using the similar argument. Therefore, both $x_1$ and $x_2$ must be either odd or even. 

Suppose both $x_1$ and $x_2$ are odd. Then $f(x_1) = f(x_2) \Rightarrow x_1 + 1 = x_2 + 1 \Rightarrow x_1 = x_2$. 

Similarly, if both $x_1$ and $x_2$ are even, then also $f(x_1) = f(x_2) \Rightarrow x_1 - 1 = x_2 - 1 \Rightarrow x_1 = x_2$. 

Thus, $f$ is one-one. 

Also, any odd number $2r + 1$ in the co-domain $\mathbb{N}$ is the image of $2r + 2$ in the domain $\mathbb{N}$ and any even number $2r$ in the co-domain $\mathbb{N}$ is the image of $2r - 1$ in the domain $\mathbb{N}$. 

Thus, $f$ is onto.
